title: What Are Roses on Hinge? And Should You Send Them?

steps.title: If you see somebody on Discover or Standouts that you really like, give them a Rose to show your interest.
steps.content: If you see somebody on Discover or Standouts that you really like, give them a Rose to show your interest. When you send a Rose, you'll show up at the top of the person's "Likes You" screen! Roses are Hinge's way of allowing users to show extra interest in someoneâ€”more than just "liking" them. If you've tried other dating apps, think of a Rose like a "SuperSwipe" on Bumble or a "Super Like" on Tinder.

steps.title: Find a profile you like in Discover.
steps.content: Find a profile you like in Discover. If a Hinge user who's especially intriguing pops up in Discover, send them a Rose to rise to the top of their Likes You screen.

steps.title: Type a comment (optional).
steps.content: Type a comment (optional). Whether you're sending a Rose from a person's photo or prompt answer , adding a comment to send with your Rose will make the action more personal.

steps.title: Tap the Rose.
steps.content: Tap the Rose. Instead of choosing "Send Like," choose the Rose icon. The Rose is now sent! [1] X Research source

steps.title: Find a profile you really like.
steps.content: Find a profile you really like. You can send Roses on Hinge from both the Discover feed and your Standouts. Hinge offers one free Rose each week. Make sure you use it, as Roses do not accumulate! Additional Roses are available for purchase. To see your Standouts, which are featured profiles that Hinge thinks you'll like, just tap the star at the bottom of the app. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the red heart on the user's photo or prompt response.
steps.content: Tap the red heart on the user's photo or prompt response. If you found the person's profile in Discover, tap the heart. If you're checking out your Standouts, tap the Rose icon instead.

steps.title: Type a comment (optional).
steps.content: Type a comment (optional). Whether you're sending a Rose from a person's photo or prompt answer , adding a comment to send with your Rose will make the action more personal. It also gives you a chance to start a conversation!

steps.title: Tap the Rose icon or Send Rose.
steps.content: Tap the Rose icon or Send Rose . The rose is now sent! [3] X Research source Roses received are represented by a red heart or speech bubble. If you receive a Rose, you will see a red heart (or a speech bubble if they left a comment) atop their profile in your "Likes You" deck. If you don't have any Roses, you'll be prompted to buy them.

steps.title: Perfect your profile before sending Roses.
steps.content: Perfect your profile before sending Roses. Roses may be a valuable feature on Hinge, but they won't get you far if you do not have a strong profile in the first place. This wikiHow article can help you create the best Hinge profile possible!

steps.title: Prepare a few compliments or openers.
steps.content: Prepare a few compliments or openers. While you can send a Rose without a compliment, including some text will make it much more impactful. Try to respond naturally to someone's photo or prompt. If you are struggling, this wikiHow article offers some excellent opening lines on Hinge. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Consider whether you could start a conversation.
steps.content: Consider whether you could start a conversation. A Rose can be a great way to get the attention of a user who you might think would otherwise overlook you. But if you think you could have a great conversation anyway, consider laying off the Rose.

steps.title: Roses go to the front of a user's "Likes You" deck.
steps.content: Roses go to the front of a user's "Likes You" deck. Both Roses and Likes notify the other user, and both can include an attached comment. But only Roses immediately send your profile to the top of another user's "Likes You" deck.

steps.title: Likes are free, but Roses cost money.
steps.content: Likes are free, but Roses cost money. While there is still a limit on the number of likes you can use, they do not cost you anything. Roses require you to pay after you use your weekly free one. [5] X Research source Because Likes are free, you may want to consider sending one when a Rose is not available.
